Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Availability and Utilization of Key Healthcare Resources during the COVID-19 Pandemic in Rural Texas

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: The COVID-19 pandemic has affected urban and rural populations quite differently. Because of the high degree of community transmission, large, densely populated urban centers have experienced the vast majority of casualties in the early phases of the pandemic, but rural hospitals have also been affected as the pandemic spreads across the country. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant will support the collection of time-sensitive data to document preparedness levels at rural hospitals over the course of the pandemic. Through a collaboration with the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS), this project will collect and archive data from four trauma regions (two rural, two urban) to identify unique challenges and opportunities faced by rural hospitals. COVID-19 is expected to eventually reach rural communities before an effective vaccine is available and the project has the potential to provide decision support to public health administrators to better manage critical resources during a pandemic or other mass casualty event. <br/><br/>Working with the Center for Health Statistics of the Texas DSHS, this project will collect longitudinal data regarding COVID-19 testing, case reports, staffed hospital and ICU beds, deidentified admission and discharge data, and outpatient procedures for hospitals in four regions of the state of Texas. The project will also collect valuable subjective data by interviewing hospital decision-makers about their operational decisions. By collecting these data from regions supporting both rural and urban healthcare systems, the project will provide useful information on differences in urban and rural healthcare system response to the COVID-19 pandemic.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant supported the collection of time-sensitive data to document preparedness levels at rural hospitals over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic. Through a collaboration with the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS), this project collected and studied data from four trauma regions (two rural, two urban) to identify unique challenges and opportunities faced by rural hospitals. The project findings provide insights that could be useful for public health administrators to better manage critical resources during a pandemic in the future.

The primary innovation of this research was to relate pandemic uncertainty factors to the operational planning of inpatient and outpatient healthcare facilities in rural areas. The data collection considered all the important factors affecting the availability and utilization of key healthcare resources during the COVID-19 pandemic in rural Texas. The most important findings of this research are discussed next.

Smaller and rural communities struggled to get diagnostic tests.  Small and rural towns were not prioritized by the government and some of them did not have the financial flexibility to buy tests them from the private sector, which oversaw most tests in Texas. Epidemiologists stated that tests are crucial to understanding the spread of the virus, including in rural and semi-urban areas with limited health care infrastructure that could be overwhelmed by a small cluster of cases.

The statewide mask mandate in Texas helped to change the increasing trend for the number of new cases and hospitalizations observed for all hospital trauma service regions (TSRs) considered in this research. Business capacity restrictions showed to be productive in reducing the spread. A second increasing trend was observed for all TSRs after capacity restrictions were lifted for business (i.e., bars reopen) in October 2020. Community events (i.e., carnivals) conducted without proper guidelines showed to have a negative impact in the number of hospitalizations and fatalities in a community.

In terms of PPE, healthcare workers on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic encountered shortage of masks, gowns, face shields and gloves during the first five months of the crisis. Nurses reported that they were reusing N95 masks for days and even weeks at a time. Doctors were unable to reopen their practices because they did not have access to PPE. PPE data was very limited and difficult to collect. Our team surveyed hospitals in the four TSR considered in this study and aggregated the results due to the limited number of responses received per TSR. The collected data showed that less than 50% of the hospitals reported no PPE supply challenge by the end of 2020. The inability to secure PPE was frustrating for healthcare workers because it is their main defense against the coronavirus.

This project directly and indirectly supported the work and participation of underrepresented minority students in engineering. Two undergraduate female students, Holly Streber and Kayla Streber, won the Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers (IISE) Operations Research Division Undergraduate Student Research Dissemination Competition at the  2022 IISE annual Conference with their project Optimizing the Texas Trauma Network.
